cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the Spanish language for beginning students; overview of basic grammatical structures, development of vocabulary and oral and written expression.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish for Beginners
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: No previous knowledge of Spanish, or placement test results.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Tutorial times are incorporated into each lecture time. The department will contact you regarding your tutorial room when classes begin.

cmCourseInfo.description: For native (heritage) speakers who have had exposure to spoken Spanish in an informal context (i.e, living in a Spanish-speaking country; or with a Spanish-speaking family), but little to no exposure to written Spanish. The students' ability to speak and understand Spanish may range from basic to relatively high fluency, but they cannot write and/or read Spanish. The course reviews English/Spanish spelling differences; written and spoken registers of Spanish, and basic aspects of the grammatical system. Provides students with the essential understanding of Spanish grammatical system; builds their vocabulary; and trains them to express themselves formally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Academic Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Basic to relatively high native ability to speak and understand Spanish; limited or no formal education in Spanish.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Students must enroll in the mandatory tutorial section on ACORN.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Tutorial Time: Tues & Thurs 11:00-12:0. Room changed: Oct. 5, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: Intermediate Spanish for non-native speakers. Intensive grammar review of the structures of Spanish integrated with an introduction to reading authentic Spanish material, with practice designed to build vocabulary and to improve oral and written expression.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA100Y1 or placement test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Tutorial times are incorporated into each lecture time. The department will contact you regarding your tutorial room when classes begin.

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to articulatory phonetics, Spanish sound patterns, phonetics, phonology; the basic concepts of phonetic description and transcription; the study of Spanish vowel and consonant systems, stress and intonation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Pronunciation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA100Y1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA219Y1; native speakers of Spanish; SPA321H1

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to university literary studies in Spanish and information literacy. Representative selection of Spanish and Spanish American prose, poetry, and drama, with focus on critical terminology and methods of literary analysis. Required for a program degree.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literary Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: First semester SPA220Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to university literary studies in Spanish and information literacy. Representative selection of Spanish and Spanish American prose, poetry, and drama, with focus on critical terminology and methods of literary analysis. Required for a program degree.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literary Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: First semester SPA220Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Spanish for non-natives. Selective review of grammar with emphasis on the complex sentence; intensive practice in written and oral expression to improve proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA220Y1 or placement test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Tutorial times are incorporated into each lecture time. The department will contact you regarding your tutorial room when classes begin.

cmCourseInfo.description: The basic concepts and analytic tools of linguistics applied to the study of Spanish, with a focus on the Spanish phonological, morphological, and syntactic systems. Theoretical discussion and practical exercises in analytic techniques.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA220Y1/SPA219Y1; or instructor's permission

courses.name: Spanish and the Empire: Migration in Language and Literature

cmCourseInfo.description: This interdisciplinary approach considers broad cultural consequences resulting from the contact of Spanish with the American indigenous languages. Current cultural and linguistic theories on language contact are used to analyze sixteenth to eighteenth-century Spanish texts, and invite reflection on language, power, and the emergence of new cultural expressions. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish and the Empire: Migration in Language and Literature
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA219Y1 / SPA220Y1

courses.name: Nation, Identity and Modernity in Spanish-America

cmCourseInfo.description: Analysis of poetry, short stories, essays, and graphic art in the context of nation-building and the question of identity during the nineteenth century. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Nation, Identity and Modernity in Spanish-America
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA220Y1/SPA219Y1

courses.name: Literature and Social Change in Spanish America

cmCourseInfo.description: Detailed study of key moments and texts in Spanish American culture from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, focusing on such topics as the creation of new nations, indigenismo, Caribbean anti-slavery literature, and the Mexican and Cuban Revolutions. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Literature and Social Change in Spanish America
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA220Y1/SPA219Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: Linguistic analysis with the objective of improving students' command of Spanish grammar. Advanced review of traditional grammatical topics, including the verbal and pronominal systems, and Spanish copulas and embedded clauses. This course assumes familiarity with the grammatical terminology introduced in SPA220Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Grammar
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA219Y1/SPA320Y1, or placement test.

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical and experimental approaches to Spanish phonology. Topics include: Spanish phonemic inventory, sound patterns, suprasegmentals (stress and intonation), synchronic and diachronic variation. Methods of data collection and analysis in the discipline, with practical applications. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Phonology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA322H1 or permission of the Department

courses.name: Literature and Society in Medieval Iberia

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of medieval social topics such as witchcraft, violence, love, marriage, childhood, maternity, crimes and punishment. Analysis of such texts as Poema del Mio Cid; the Romancero, Milagros de Nuestra Seora, Libro de buen amor, Don Juan Manuel and Celestina, from the perspective of iconography and social history. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Literature and Society in Medieval Iberia
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

cmCourseInfo.description: Detailed study of Don Quixote as a foundational text in the European literary tradition, with attention to the conventions, genres, and literary techniques that inform the text.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cervantes: Don Quixote
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

courses.name: Topics in Spanish-American Literature and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on a specific topic in Spanish American culture, designed for advanced students. Course content and instructor are established on a yearly basis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

courses.name: Topics in Spanish-American Literature and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on a specific topic in Spanish American culture, designed for advanced students. Course content and instructor are established on a yearly basis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

cmCourseInfo.description: Contemporary Argentine and Mexican authors and visual artists will be tudied through their work, online visibility, and also the institutional and discursive structures that facilitate and shape their production. In-class Skype discussions with some of the artists. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: 21st Century Latin American Culture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

cmCourseInfo.description: Detailed study of the major movements in Spanish-American narrative, including magic realism, fantastic literature, womens writing, and testimonial literature, through analysis of representative novels and short stories. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: 20th-Century Spanish American Narrative
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

cmCourseInfo.description: The end of civil and military conflicts in the last decade of the 20th century reshapes the political landscape of Central America. Through selected readings of novels and short stories from representative writers, issues of immigration, displacement, and globalization are discussed to understand these changes in the region. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Central America Postwar Narrative
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.
